description.narrative: NRC is Norway’s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida's Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC's capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida's humanitarian unit's annual budget appropriation which is substantial. The objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: "To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors." It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. NRC’s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. Sida's Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC's method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). More specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras/El Salvador/Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania/Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. As an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: 26% for Shelter and settlements, 20% for Education, 17% for Livelihoods and Food Security, 14% for ICLA, 9% for WASH, 3% for Camp Management and 11% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. The good scores of NRC in ITAD's evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. Describing NRC's activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC's work. SHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC's expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in protracted displacement situations. LIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON/Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten livelihoods and individuals' and households' abilities to earn a living. ICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one's rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC's lawyers. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Support to people to claim and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face particular obstacles in accessing their rights. EDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has been training teachers and school personnel in Burundi to absorb the additional numbers of returnee youth who were Burundian refugees born in Tanzania that are enrolling in ill-prepared Burundian schools, at the best interest of the students, including protection aspects. Students had to be assisted for shifting overnight from Kiswahili and English-language curriculas to Kirundi and French-language curriculas. By doing that NRC, not only restaures education rights, but contributes to the local social cohesion. NRC is involved in the global Education Cannot Wait through advocacy. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Support to children and youth to complete a full cycle of basic education with particular focus on those who are out of school or have had their education interrupted. Provision of technical and vocational training for young adults. CAMP MANAGEMENT: NRC showed further its protection work to Sida in Azraq and Zaatari refugee camps in Jordan, designed for accommodating social cases, un-documented individuals and alleged security threats, including un-accompanied minors, who could not be left free in the society according to the authorities. NRC would turn the experience of detention, in the middle of nowhere, desertic in fact, less depressing by upgrading shelter conditions, and providing education services, vocational training and psychosocial support, including assisting refugees to negotiate temporary exit permits. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Camp management, in and outside of camp settings. Camp management core functions include coordinating and monitoring assistance and protection, setting up and supporting governance and community participation mechanisms, managing and disseminating information, providing multisector feedback mechanisms, and maintaining infrastructure. WASH: Five year into their displacement situation, Syrian refugees in Lebanon were still provided with 15 L/person/day drinkable water through costly water-trucking deliveries serving around 285,000 people living in thousands of informal tented settlements (ITS) of the Bekaa valley. Central authorities were blocking any improvements, like drilling wells, that would result in permanenting the refugee settlements in the country or giving the refugees the hope that they have a future in Lebanon. NRC managed to negotiate with communal councils, eager to improve their own infrastructures needing maintainance since the Civil War, that certain settlements along main roads would be connected to the local water systems. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Provision of infrastructre for water and sanitation, and information dissemination on good hygiene practices. Sida has evidence that NRC is aligning fully its own response strategies on the HRPs, which is a condition for receiving Sida's funding. NRC is usually an active stakeholder of the process of elaborating such plans, inter alia through its engagement in participating in or co-leading clusters of the local humanitarian system (potentially in its core competencies sectors) depending on locations, and through hosting NGO coordination forums. RRM Allocation 2021 Included in this contribution, it is proposed to support NRC's capacity to address new emerging humanitarian needs in rapid onset crises. Sida's funding Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) allocation to NRC will enable NRC to react very fast to new disasters when they strike. It may provide seed funding to larger response programmes and catalyze more resources, complementing as well the resources that the flexibility of PBA provides for re-allocating them in such circumstances, when possible. In 2020, NRC tapped into its 50 MSEK allocation 15 times, replenished once, until it was exhausted, intervening in 13 countries where NRC had presence in the context of sudden displacement situations, floods, droughts and socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 on displaced and vulnerable households. The assistance provided consisted generally in protection services and assistance delivered in form of cash, vouchers, and in-kind life-saving commodities, in the areas of shelter, basic assistance kits, hygiene promotion and psychosocial support. In 2021, NRC will undertake similar interventions with the RRM allocation with an initial 40 MSEK funding from Sida. RRM interventions are considered as projects, implemented over a 3 to 6 month period, with a 3 MSEK budget in average. The ceiling is 5 MSEK, while the bottom budget is 2 MSEK, but exceptions can be justified case by case. Method- and capacity-building projects Included in this contribution, NRC has proposed to Sida to support Method- and capacity-building projects that will contribute to improve the global humanitarian system and coordination & advocacy forums at the national level. - Strengthening global protection policy for displacement communities is a project that Sida is willing to prioritize as it focuses on ensuring effective integration of protection across NRC programming and improvements to global humanitarian protection policy by translating concepts into concrete actionable outcomes. This project aims at ensuring that protection is foundational to all NRC work through the ‘Safe Programming’ framework defining minimum commitments for NRC's operations, and at supporting the full realisation of the right of freedom of movement in safety and dignity for displacement-affected persons, in programmes for the protection of civilians, for durable solutions and for migrants in 'refugee-like' situations. - Becoming the leading displacement organization in hard to reach areas (H2R) is a project that will be supported in 2021 by Sida. It addresses the growing complexity of operating environments by investing in in-depth understanding of contexts against the backdrop of shifting international norms and the rise of new tech solutions to ensure timely and appropriate responses. NRC wants to ensure that displacement-affected individuals considered hard-to-reach have better access to assistance and protection, by enhancing NRC's ability to access multiple geographical and cultural H2R contexts, by delivering high quality and sustained programming in H2R areas and by advocating for the rights of people affected by displacement in H2R areas. - Sida's support to NRC's CashCap will be continued in 2021. The project ensures that humanitarian/development agencies and national actors have sufficient and sustained expertise to design and implement cash and market-based response (CMBR) in an effective and coordinated manner. NRC intends to ensure global rapid deployment capacity for the initial days of a sudden onset emergency and to enable the systematic consideration of cash and voucher assistance as part of the initial response analysis. NRC will facilitate knowledge exchange, provide technical backstop and support to CashCap roster members on deployment, and improve sustainability between CashCap expert and cash community by sharing information, promoting continuity and encouraging to take ownership by the cash community. - NRC’s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) in Geneva will continue to be co-financed by Sida's humanitarian unit and Sida's unit for Global Cooperation on Environment in 2021. IDMC is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country. It is known for its research publications and advocacy aiming at generating evidence on all situations of internal displacement; building capacity to prevent and respond to the issue; and galvanising political commitment and action to drive positive change. For the second and probably last year, Sida's Unit for Global Cooperation on Environment will co-finance IDMC in 2021 together with the Humanitarian Unit, as IDMC analyzes displacement situation trends caused by climate change as well. IDMC adds great value to the evidence- and needs-based mobilization of resources for displacement situations. Its analysis and research are major contributions to the global and local advocacy agenda. - NRC will be supported as well through this contribution for hosting local humanitarian coordination platforms where international and local NGOs cooperate for building up coordinated programmes, common advocacy agendas and for influencing the policy-making of authorities, the UN, donors and other partners. These forums play a key role in localizing the response, offering coordination services, training and partnership opportunities to the local NGO community. They play as well an important role for INGOs in addressing administrative and access obstacles that they may face with authorities for establishing themselves and obtaining visas and work permits. The Jordan INGO Forum and the Libya INGO Forum will be supported through this contribution. NRC's active engagement in the local NGO forums, sometimes by hosting them with Sida's support (DRC, Palestine (AIDA), Jordan, Libya, Lebanon until (2019)), demonstrates NRC's commitment to aid effectiveness and collective action regarding humanitarian coordination and advocacy. - Furthermore, it is proposed to continue co-financing for a last year the West Bank Protection Consortium (WBPC) with the Swedish General Consulate in Jerusalem and other donors. It is a strategic partnership between DG ECHO, 10 European States and 5 INGOs providing protection and assistance to Palestinians at risk of forcible transfer in the West Bank due to recurrent violations of international law. The project addresses the protection needs of persons and communities of concern through a multi-sector approach that reduces vulnerabilities, builds capacities and responds to threats. The Consulate has established a 3 year partnership 2021-2023 with NRC (#14571, 39 MSEK) for that project. The WBPC project, and the NGO platform AIDA, supported so far by Sida's humanitarian unit, will be funded by Sweden's development cooperation strategy for Palestine, integrated in that contribution.

Norwegian Refugee Council - Norska flyktingrådet (NRC) - har ansökt om ett förnyat partnerskap med Sida 2021-2025. NRC har dessutom ansökt om finansiering på 364,5 miljoner SEK för att genomföra humanitära insatser i 26 humanitära krisområden under 2021: Afghanistan, Kamerun, Centralafrikanska republiken, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Demokratiska Republiken Kongo, Eritrea, Etiopien, Iran, Irak, Jordanien, Kenya, Libanon, Libyen, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexiko, Palestina, Somalia, Sydsudan, Sudan, Tanzania / Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela och Jemen. Ansökan inkluderar även 40 miljoner kronor för den humanitära snabbmekanismen (RRM) och 20 miljoner kronor i stöd till sju projekt för metodstöd, kapacitetsuppbyggnad och samordning.
NRC:s mål är att i krissituationer skydda fördrivna och utsatta människor, värna deras rättigheter och bistå med assistans för att möta deras omedelbara humanitära behov, förhindra ytterligare fördrivning, samt bidra till hållbara lösningar. Dessutom tillhandahåller NRC expertis som en strategisk partner för det humanitära systemet och dess olika aktörer. NRC bedriver också principbaserat och tydligt påverkanarbete för att utöva inflytande på beslutsfattare. NRC planerar att under 2021 bistå 7,263,000 personer med humanitära behov.
NRC bygger sina program med människor i centrum, och med särskild inriktning på personer som har tvingats på flykt. Det är en rättighetsbaserad organisation som verkar för att ge skydd åt de mest utsatta och sårbara och hjälpa dem att återuppbygga sina liv. NRC arbetar därför alltid för hållbara lösningar när de genomför humanitära projekt och program. Organisationen integrerar även humanitär medling och förhandling mellan olika parter i samhället i sina program och på så sätt kan organisationen även bidra till en fredliga lösningar på lånvariga konflikter. NRC:s programmering stävar efter att stärka kopplingar mellan humanitärt bistånd, utveckling och fred.
NRC kommer i huvudsak att genomföra insatsen på egen hand, genom organisationens 7 700 anställda och 7 000 volontärer som mobilisera i de områdena där insatsen genomförs.
Den aktuella budgeten för NRC:s hela humanitära program 2021 uppgår till 4 263 200 000 NOK, varav Sidas del för närvarande utgör ca 8%. Givare, som det norska utrikesministeriet, GD ECHO, UNHCR, etc. bidrar med större volymer och ytterligare ett tiotal andra givare har ingått avtal med NRC. Sida ger NRC möjligheten att nyttja resurser flexibelt inom varje enskilt landprogram, (enligt så kallad Programme-Based Approach – PBA)
Humanitär-Utveckling-Fred Nexus NRC bidrar i hög grad till arbetet för att sammankoppla humanitärt bistånd med freds- och utvecklingsinsatser. Organisationens strävan att effektivisera biståndet genom katalytiskt stöd till samordning och kapacitetsbyggande insatser bidrar till denna ansats. I samarbetet med andra organisationer möjliggör och bidrar NRC:s verksamhet och påverkansarbete till att stärka hållbara lösningar för flyktingar och människor som har blivit tvångsfördrivna och bidrar därmed till att på sikt minska de humanitära behoven. Även krisdrabbade människors möjligheter till självförsörjning prioriteras. NRC:s analyskapacitet är en styrka som bidrar till att programmeringen anpassas till en nexus-ansats och den analys som genomförs av NRC:s internationella center för övervakning av tvångsförflyttning (IDMC) är av stor vikt för dessa analyser. 15 av de 26 kriser i NRC:s portfölj som Sida finansierar avser länder där Sverige även bedriver utvecklingssamarbete vilket öppnar för möjligheter till synergier med humanitärt bistånd.
Tillägg beslut för att stödja IASC Skydd Översyn genom NRC bidar med ytterligare 1,2 mkr till NRC 2021.
Reservallokering 2021 bidrar med 40 mkr totalt till NRC (Colombia och Venezuela regionalt 5 + 5 mkr, Mali 5 mkr, Mozambique 7,5 mkr, Niger 7,5 mkr, Syrien 10 mkr). Mozambique är nytt.

NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Support to people to claim and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face particular obstacles in accessing their rights. EDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has been training teachers and school personnel in Burundi to absorb the additional numbers of returnee youth who were Burundian refugees born in Tanzania that are enrolling in ill-prepared Burundian schools, at the best interest of the students, including protection aspects. Students had to be assisted for shifting overnight from Kiswahili and English-language curriculas to Kirundi and French-language curriculas. By doing that NRC, not only restaures education rights, but contributes to the local social cohesion. NRC is involved in the global Education Cannot Wait through advocacy. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Support to children and youth to complete a full cycle of basic education with particular focus on those who are out of school or have had their education interrupted. Provision of technical and vocational training for young adults. CAMP MANAGEMENT: NRC showed further its protection work to Sida in Azraq and Zaatari refugee camps in Jordan, designed for accommodating social cases, un-documented individuals and alleged security threats, including un-accompanied minors, who could not be left free in the society according to the authorities. NRC would turn the experience of detention, in the middle of nowhere, desertic in fact, less depressing by upgrading shelter conditions, and providing education services, vocational training and psychosocial support, including assisting refugees to negotiate temporary exit permits. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Camp management, in and outside of camp settings. Camp management core functions include coordinating and monitoring assistance and protection, setting up and supporting governance and community participation mechanisms, managing and disseminating information, providing multisector feedback mechanisms, and maintaining infrastructure. WASH: Five year into their displacement situation, Syrian refugees in Lebanon were still provided with 15 L/person/day drinkable water through costly water-trucking deliveries serving around 285,000 people living in thousands of informal tented settlements (ITS) of the Bekaa valley. Central authorities were blocking any improvements, like drilling wells, that would result in permanenting the refugee settlements in the country or giving the refugees the hope that they have a future in Lebanon. NRC managed to negotiate with communal councils, eager to improve their own infrastructures needing maintainance since the Civil War, that certain settlements along main roads would be connected to the local water systems. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Provision of infrastructre for water and sanitation, and information dissemination on good hygiene practices. Sida has evidence that NRC is aligning fully its own response strategies on the HRPs, which is a condition for receiving Sida's funding. NRC is usually an active stakeholder of the process of elaborating such plans, inter alia through its engagement in participating in or co-leading clusters of the local humanitarian system (potentially in its core competencies sectors) depending on locations, and through hosting NGO coordination forums. RRM Allocation 2021 Included in this contribution, it is proposed to support NRC's capacity to address new emerging humanitarian needs in rapid onset crises. Sida's funding Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) allocation to NRC will enable NRC to react very fast to new disasters when they strike. It may provide seed funding to larger response programmes and catalyze more resources, complementing as well the resources that the flexibility of PBA provides for re-allocating them in such circumstances, when possible. In 2020, NRC tapped into its 50 MSEK allocation 15 times, replenished once, until it was exhausted, intervening in 13 countries where NRC had presence in the context of sudden displacement situations, floods, droughts and socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 on displaced and vulnerable households. The assistance provided consisted generally in protection services and assistance delivered in form of cash, vouchers, and in-kind life-saving commodities, in the areas of shelter, basic assistance kits, hygiene promotion and psychosocial support. In 2021, NRC will undertake similar interventions with the RRM allocation with an initial 40 MSEK funding from Sida. RRM interventions are considered as projects, implemented over a 3 to 6 month period, with a 3 MSEK budget in average. The ceiling is 5 MSEK, while the bottom budget is 2 MSEK, but exceptions can be justified case by case. Method- and capacity-building projects Included in this contribution, NRC has proposed to Sida to support Method- and capacity-building projects that will contribute to improve the global humanitarian system and coordination & advocacy forums at the national level. - Strengthening global protection policy for displacement communities is a project that Sida is willing to prioritize as it focuses on ensuring effective integration of protection across NRC programming and improvements to global humanitarian protection policy by translating concepts into concrete actionable outcomes. This project aims at ensuring that protection is foundational to all NRC work through the ‘Safe Programming’ framework defining minimum commitments for NRC's operations, and at supporting the full realisation of the right of freedom of movement in safety and dignity for displacement-affected persons, in programmes for the protection of civilians, for durable solutions and for migrants in 'refugee-like' situations. - Becoming the leading displacement organization in hard to reach areas (H2R) is a project that will be supported in 2021 by Sida. It addresses the growing complexity of operating environments by investing in in-depth understanding of contexts against the backdrop of shifting international norms and the rise of new tech solutions to ensure timely and appropriate responses. NRC wants to ensure that displacement-affected individuals considered hard-to-reach have better access to assistance and protection, by enhancing NRC's ability to access multiple geographical and cultural H2R contexts, by delivering high quality and sustained programming in H2R areas and by advocating for the rights of people affected by displacement in H2R areas. - Sida's support to NRC's CashCap will be continued in 2021. The project ensures that humanitarian/development agencies and national actors have sufficient and sustained expertise to design and implement cash and market-based response (CMBR) in an effective and coordinated manner. NRC intends to ensure global rapid deployment capacity for the initial days of a sudden onset emergency and to enable the systematic consideration of cash and voucher assistance as part of the initial response analysis. NRC will facilitate knowledge exchange, provide technical backstop and support to CashCap roster members on deployment, and improve sustainability between CashCap expert and cash community by sharing information, promoting continuity and encouraging to take ownership by the cash community. - NRC’s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) in Geneva will continue to be co-financed by Sida's humanitarian unit and Sida's unit for Global Cooperation on Environment in 2021. IDMC is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country. It is known for its research publications and advocacy aiming at generating evidence on all situations of internal displacement; building capacity to prevent and respond to the issue; and galvanising political commitment and action to drive positive change. For the second and probably last year, Sida's Unit for Global Cooperation on Environment will co-finance IDMC in 2021 together with the Humanitarian Unit, as IDMC analyzes displacement situation trends caused by climate change as well. IDMC adds great value to the evidence- and needs-based mobilization of resources for displacement situations. Its analysis and research are major contributions to the global and local advocacy agenda. - NRC will be supported as well through this contribution for hosting local humanitarian coordination platforms where international and local NGOs cooperate for building up coordinated programmes, common advocacy agendas and for influencing the policy-making of authorities, the UN, donors and other partners. These forums play a key role in localizing the response, offering coordination services, training and partnership opportunities to the local NGO community. They play as well an important role for INGOs in addressing administrative and access obstacles that they may face with authorities for establishing themselves and obtaining visas and work permits. The Jordan INGO Forum and the Libya INGO Forum will be supported through this contribution. NRC's active engagement in the local NGO forums, sometimes by hosting them with Sida's support (DRC, Palestine (AIDA), Jordan, Libya, Lebanon until (2019)), demonstrates NRC's commitment to aid effectiveness and collective action regarding humanitarian coordination and advocacy. - Furthermore, it is proposed to continue co-financing for a last year the West Bank Protection Consortium (WBPC) with the Swedish General Consulate in Jerusalem and other donors. It is a strategic partnership between DG ECHO, 10 European States and 5 INGOs providing protection and assistance to Palestinians at risk of forcible transfer in the West Bank due to recurrent violations of international law. The project addresses the protection needs of persons and communities of concern through a multi-sector approach that reduces vulnerabilities, builds capacities and responds to threats. The Consulate has established a 3 year partnership 2021-2023 with NRC (#14571, 39 MSEK) for that project. The WBPC project, and the NGO platform AIDA, supported so far by Sida's humanitarian unit, will be funded by Sweden's development cooperation strategy for Palestine, integrated in that contribution.

Norwegian Refugee Council - Norska flyktingrådet (NRC) - har ansökt om ett förnyat partnerskap med Sida 2021-2025. NRC har dessutom ansökt om finansiering på 364,5 miljoner SEK för att genomföra humanitära insatser i 26 humanitära krisområden under 2021: Afghanistan, Kamerun, Centralafrikanska republiken, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Demokratiska Republiken Kongo, Eritrea, Etiopien, Iran, Irak, Jordanien, Kenya, Libanon, Libyen, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexiko, Palestina, Somalia, Sydsudan, Sudan, Tanzania / Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela och Jemen. Ansökan inkluderar även 40 miljoner kronor för den humanitära snabbmekanismen (RRM) och 20 miljoner kronor i stöd till sju projekt för metodstöd, kapacitetsuppbyggnad och samordning.
NRC:s mål är att i krissituationer skydda fördrivna och utsatta människor, värna deras rättigheter och bistå med assistans för att möta deras omedelbara humanitära behov, förhindra ytterligare fördrivning, samt bidra till hållbara lösningar. Dessutom tillhandahåller NRC expertis som en strategisk partner för det humanitära systemet och dess olika aktörer. NRC bedriver också principbaserat och tydligt påverkanarbete för att utöva inflytande på beslutsfattare. NRC planerar att under 2021 bistå 7,263,000 personer med humanitära behov.
NRC bygger sina program med människor i centrum, och med särskild inriktning på personer som har tvingats på flykt. Det är en rättighetsbaserad organisation som verkar för att ge skydd åt de mest utsatta och sårbara och hjälpa dem att återuppbygga sina liv. NRC arbetar därför alltid för hållbara lösningar när de genomför humanitära projekt och program. Organisationen integrerar även humanitär medling och förhandling mellan olika parter i samhället i sina program och på så sätt kan organisationen även bidra till en fredliga lösningar på lånvariga konflikter. NRC:s programmering stävar efter att stärka kopplingar mellan humanitärt bistånd, utveckling och fred.
NRC kommer i huvudsak att genomföra insatsen på egen hand, genom organisationens 7 700 anställda och 7 000 volontärer som mobilisera i de områdena där insatsen genomförs.
Den aktuella budgeten för NRC:s hela humanitära program 2021 uppgår till 4 263 200 000 NOK, varav Sidas del för närvarande utgör ca 8%. Givare, som det norska utrikesministeriet, GD ECHO, UNHCR, etc. bidrar med större volymer och ytterligare ett tiotal andra givare har ingått avtal med NRC. Sida ger NRC möjligheten att nyttja resurser flexibelt inom varje enskilt landprogram, (enligt så kallad Programme-Based Approach – PBA)
Humanitär-Utveckling-Fred Nexus NRC bidrar i hög grad till arbetet för att sammankoppla humanitärt bistånd med freds- och utvecklingsinsatser. Organisationens strävan att effektivisera biståndet genom katalytiskt stöd till samordning och kapacitetsbyggande insatser bidrar till denna ansats. I samarbetet med andra organisationer möjliggör och bidrar NRC:s verksamhet och påverkansarbete till att stärka hållbara lösningar för flyktingar och människor som har blivit tvångsfördrivna och bidrar därmed till att på sikt minska de humanitära behoven. Även krisdrabbade människors möjligheter till självförsörjning prioriteras. NRC:s analyskapacitet är en styrka som bidrar till att programmeringen anpassas till en nexus-ansats och den analys som genomförs av NRC:s internationella center för övervakning av tvångsförflyttning (IDMC) är av stor vikt för dessa analyser. 15 av de 26 kriser i NRC:s portfölj som Sida finansierar avser länder där Sverige även bedriver utvecklingssamarbete vilket öppnar för möjligheter till synergier med humanitärt bistånd.
Tillägg beslut för att stödja IASC Skydd Översyn genom NRC bidar med ytterligare 1,2 mkr till NRC 2021.
Reservallokering 2021 bidrar med 40 mkr totalt till NRC (Colombia och Venezuela regionalt 5 + 5 mkr, Mali 5 mkr, Mozambique 7,5 mkr, Niger 7,5 mkr, Syrien 10 mkr). Mozambique är nytt.

The Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) has applied for a renewed strategic partnership with Sida during 2021-2025. NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out “the Humanitarian Programme for 2021” in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania/Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. The application includes provision of 40 million SEK to replenish the Rapid Response Mechanism funding instrument and 7 individual projects for method, capacity-building and coordination.
The objectives of NRC’s intervention is to protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. NRC's principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021.
NRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRC's programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus.
NRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.
The intervention’s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sida’s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR, etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach – PBA).
Humanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus NRC's catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRC's advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRC's analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRC's portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Sweden's development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.
1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASC's review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC.
40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and/or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC.

description.narrative: NRC is Norway’s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida's Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC's capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida's humanitarian unit's annual budget appropriation which is substantial. The objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: "To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors." It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. NRC’s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. Sida's Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC's method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). More specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras/El Salvador/Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania/Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. As an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: 26% for Shelter and settlements, 20% for Education, 17% for Livelihoods and Food Security, 14% for ICLA, 9% for WASH, 3% for Camp Management and 11% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. The good scores of NRC in ITAD's evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. Describing NRC's activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC's work. SHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC's expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in protracted displacement situations. LIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON/Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. Norwegian Refugee Council - Norska flyktingrådet (NRC) - har ansökt om ett förnyat partnerskap med Sida 2021-2025. NRC har dessutom ansökt om finansiering på 364,5 miljoner SEK för att genomföra humanitära insatser i 26 humanitära krisområden under 2021: Afghanistan, Kamerun, Centralafrikanska republiken, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Demokratiska Republiken Kongo, Eritrea, Etiopien, Iran, Irak, Jordanien, Kenya, Libanon, Libyen, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexiko, Palestina, Somalia, Sydsudan, Sudan, Tanzania / Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela och Jemen. Ansökan inkluderar även 40 miljoner kronor för den humanitära snabbmekanismen (RRM) och 20 miljoner kronor i stöd till sju projekt för metodstöd, kapacitetsuppbyggnad och samordning.
NRC:s mål är att i krissituationer skydda fördrivna och utsatta människor, värna deras rättigheter och bistå med assistans för att möta deras omedelbara humanitära behov, förhindra ytterligare fördrivning, samt bidra till hållbara lösningar. Dessutom tillhandahåller NRC expertis som en strategisk partner för det humanitära systemet och dess olika aktörer. NRC bedriver också principbaserat och tydligt påverkanarbete för att utöva inflytande på beslutsfattare. NRC planerar att under 2021 bistå 7,263,000 personer med humanitära behov.
NRC bygger sina program med människor i centrum, och med särskild inriktning på personer som har tvingats på flykt. Det är en rättighetsbaserad organisation som verkar för att ge skydd åt de mest utsatta och sårbara och hjälpa dem att återuppbygga sina liv. NRC arbetar därför alltid för hållbara lösningar när de genomför humanitära projekt och program. Organisationen integrerar även humanitär medling och förhandling mellan olika parter i samhället i sina program och på så sätt kan organisationen även bidra till en fredliga lösningar på lånvariga konflikter. NRC:s programmering stävar efter att stärka kopplingar mellan humanitärt bistånd, utveckling och fred.
NRC kommer i huvudsak att genomföra insatsen på egen hand, genom organisationens 7 700 anställda och 7 000 volontärer som mobilisera i de områdena där insatsen genomförs.
Den aktuella budgeten för NRC:s hela humanitära program 2021 uppgår till 4 263 200 000 NOK, varav Sidas del för närvarande utgör ca 8%. Givare, som det norska utrikesministeriet, GD ECHO, UNHCR, etc. bidrar med större volymer och ytterligare ett tiotal andra givare har ingått avtal med NRC. Sida ger NRC möjligheten att nyttja resurser flexibelt inom varje enskilt landprogram, (enligt så kallad Programme-Based Approach – PBA)
Humanitär-Utveckling-Fred Nexus NRC bidrar i hög grad till arbetet för att sammankoppla humanitärt bistånd med freds- och utvecklingsinsatser. Organisationens strävan att effektivisera biståndet genom katalytiskt stöd till samordning och kapacitetsbyggande insatser bidrar till denna ansats. I samarbetet med andra organisationer möjliggör och bidrar NRC:s verksamhet och påverkansarbete till att stärka hållbara lösningar för flyktingar och människor som har blivit tvångsfördrivna och bidrar därmed till att på sikt minska de humanitära behoven. Även krisdrabbade människors möjligheter till självförsörjning prioriteras. NRC:s analyskapacitet är en styrka som bidrar till att programmeringen anpassas till en nexus-ansats och den analys som genomförs av NRC:s internationella center för övervakning av tvångsförflyttning (IDMC) är av stor vikt för dessa analyser. 15 av de 26 kriser i NRC:s portfölj som Sida finansierar avser länder där Sverige även bedriver utvecklingssamarbete vilket öppnar för möjligheter till synergier med humanitärt bistånd.
Tillägg beslut för att stödja IASC Skydd Översyn genom NRC bidar med ytterligare 1,2 mkr till NRC 2021.
Reservallokering 2021 bidrar med 40 mkr totalt till NRC (Colombia och Venezuela regionalt 5 + 5 mkr, Mali 5 mkr, Mozambique 7,5 mkr, Niger 7,5 mkr, Syrien 10 mkr). Mozambique är nytt.

The Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) has applied for a renewed strategic partnership with Sida during 2021-2025. NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out “the Humanitarian Programme for 2021” in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania/Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. The application includes provision of 40 million SEK to replenish the Rapid Response Mechanism funding instrument and 7 individual projects for method, capacity-building and coordination.
The objectives of NRC’s intervention is to protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. NRC's principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021.
NRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRC's programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus.
NRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.
The intervention’s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sida’s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR, etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach – PBA).
Humanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus NRC's catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRC's advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRC's analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRC's portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Sweden's development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.
1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASC's review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC.
40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and/or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC.

description.narrative:
Detta beslut avser ”Beslut om insats” (Insatshanteringsregeln 2.9 §) mellan Sida och FAO för att möjliggöra humanitärt stöd i fyra kriser 2021.
Beslutet omfattar finansiellt stöd till FAO om totalt 102 000 000 kronor, varav 94 000 000 kronor år 2021.
Sidas humanitära enhet har under 2020 genomfört en översyn av samtliga strategiska partners i syfte att säkerställa samarbete med de mest relevanta och effektiva humanitära aktörerna för genomförandet av Sveriges humanitära strategi genom Sida (2021-2025). Som ett resultat av översynen har Sida beslutat att bereda ny insats och ingå nytt strategiskt partnerskap med FAO, se beslut 2021-000057.
Syftet för beslutet är att stödja FAO:s humanitära verksamhet under 2021 samt ingå strategiskt partnerskap för perioden 2021 – 2025.
Genom stödet till FAO kommer Sida under 2021 bidra till FAO:s operativa verksamhet i Afghanistan, Nigeria, Somalia och Sydsudan. Vidare kommer Sida bidra med medel till FAO:s snabbinsatsmekanism SFERA samt med medel till det globala livsmedelsklustret.
Stödet utbetalas i början av året för att FAO ska ha förutsättningar att planera och genomföra humanitära insatser utan fördröjning. FAO omsätter regelmässigt utbetalda medel i nära anslutning till utbetalning och förbrukar gåvomedel inom verksamhetsåret.

The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is a specialised agency of the United Nations that leads international efforts to defeat hunger. The organisation's goal is to achieve food security for all and make sure that people have regular access to enough high-quality food to lead active, healthy lives. With over 194 member states, FAO works in over 130 countries worldwide.
FAO works side by side with the other two Rome-based UN agencies – the World Food Programme (WFP) and the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) to promote food security by alleviating hunger through emergency food assistance as well as more long-term support to eliminate the root causes of food insecurity. While WFP’s main comparative advantage lies in its capacity for large-scale food response, logistics, telecommunications and procurement capacity, the advantage of FAO lies in its role as the world’s agricultural knowledge agency with its unique agricultural expertise but also in its holistic approach to humanitarian crises, which includes analysis of the entire food system, including cultivation, harvesting, processing, packaging, transporting, marketing and consumption.
FAO also plays an important normative role, through international agreements, codes of conduct, and voluntary guidelines as well as policy dialogue at global, regional and national levels and advocacy in areas relevant to FAO’s mandate.
Alignment with strategy
The objectives of FAO are in line with the strategy for Sweden's Humanitarian Assistance through Sida (2021-2025) and through its operations, FAO is strengthening the capacity and effectiveness of the humanitarian system. The contribution is relevant for all objectives in the strategy, with an emphasis on the strategy area on protection and assistance to crisis affected populations.
This is an appraisal and subsequent decision of a new contribution (Decision on Contribution, Rule for Managing Contributions 2.9 §) between Sida and FAO, to allow for humanitarian response in four crises for 2021.
This decision also includes support for rapid response to new and deteriorating humanitarian crises through the Special Fund for Emergency and Rehabilitation Activities (SFERA) and Method-Development support through the Global Food Security Cluster.
This decision concerns a financial contribution to FAO amounting to 102 000 000 SEK.
Reasons for the decision
Evaluation 2020
During 2020, the humanitarian assistance unit at Sida conducted an overview of ongoing strategic partnerships in order to ensure that partnership was established with the most relevant and effective humanitarian actors to carry out Sweden’s strategy for humanitarian assistance through Sida (2021 – 2025). As a result of the overview, Sida has decided to appraise a new contribution and enter into a new strategic partnership agreement with FAO, see decision 2021-000057.
Comparative Advantage of FAO:
Based on the organisation’s mandate to build a world without hunger through technical cooperation and assistance, FAO has a unique role to play in humanitarian settings. Through its long-standing country presence, technical expertise in agriculture and food systems, as well as expertise and experience in both humanitarian assistance and development cooperation, FAO is well-placed to address both acute hunger as well as to support countries experiencing food crises to return to normality and building resilience to future chocks. By protecting livelihoods through emergency agricultural assistance, FAO is hence able to provide emergency interventions that save lives and safeguard livelihoods in the short-term while at the same time strengthening resilience in the face of future crises.
FAO’s comparative advantages were also highlighted by Sida’s evaluation of its strategic partners, which stated that FAO, apart from being a strong player within the thematic areas of food security and livelihoods, also demonstrated strong capacity regarding resilience and nexus programming. The evaluation also concluded that FAO has a comparative advantage in its utilisation of partnerships with local actors and development agencies, which not only ensure sustainability of its interventions but also in many cases means that FAO has good indirect access in remote and hard to reach areas. Finally, the evaluation also recognised FAO’s technical expertise as a valuable comparative advantage and highlighted FAO’s participation in technical working groups and its leadership role in the food security clusters as well as its contribution to HNO/HRP processes. Specifically, the evaluation highlighted the Sida supported FSNAU intervention as an example of an FAO intervention that was instrumental in providing early warning to the humanitarian system in Somalia, which contributed to avert famine during the severe drought in 2017.
Sida’s Humanitarian Follow Up and Field Missions to FAO Responses:
Due to the COVID-19 pandemic the staff at Sida’s unit for humanitarian assistance based in Stockholm were not able to make as many field follow-ups as per normal. Humanitarian focal points stationed in the Foreign Missions have been crucial to conduct follow-up, as well as digital tools that have allowed for remote monitoring and follow-up. Overall, the conclusions of continuous dialogue, monitoring and follow-up show that FAO is a professional humanitarian actor which, through its extensive network of partners, has the ability to gain access to very remote and hard to reach areas. Sida also notes that FAO in several contexts through its vast technical expertise, plays an important role in technical working groups and coordination fora in the project countries.
THE GLOBAL HUMANITARIAN SITUATION 2021
According to the Global Humanitarian Overview, in 2021, 235 million people will be in need of humanitarian assistance and protection – a substantial increase compared to 2020 which started out with nearly 168 million people in need. Thus resulting in yet another year with the highest number of people in need ever recorded by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). In parallel with staggering numbers of people in need, the funding gap increases and according to OCHA’s Financial Tracking Service (FTS), response plans and appeals were only 46% funded in 2020, compared to 61% in 2019. In 2021 the UN and partner organisations aim to help 160 million people most in need across 56 countries, with an estimated requirement of 35 billion USD.
Both the increase in people in need and funding gap can be partly derived from the COVID-19 pandemic. Putting additional pressure onto an already strained humanitarian system with limited resources. Although COVID-19 has definitely been centre stage during 2020, there are still other worrying trends affecting the global humanitarian outlook for 2021.
First, the COVID-19 pandemic has further exacerbated the vulnerability of the least protected populations. The pandemic has triggered the deepest global recession since the 1930s. Extreme poverty has risen for the first time in 22 years, and unemployment has increased dramatically. The impact of the socio-economic situation will continue to have serious implications on humanitarian needs in 2021.
Second, political conflicts are more intense and are taking a heavy toll on civilians, disproportionally affecting children. Women and girls are at increased risk of conflict-related sexual violence. As such, protecting those affected by armed conflict is more crucial than ever. The lack of respect for International Humanitarian Law (IHL) continues to be one of the most pressing challenges. Armed conflicts continue to cause enormous suffering, including violations of IHL, such as killings, torture, abductions and displacements. Applying a protection lens/Centrality of Protection approach is essential – in light of the protection crises such as the Syria crisis - now active for more than a decade; Yemen - being the largest humanitarian crisis worldwide; the DR Congo; the Venezuela crisis; the Nagorno-Karabach situation and the Rohingya crisis – just to mention a few.
Third, hunger is on the rise, with conflict the main driver of acute hunger for 77 million people in 22 countries. By the end of 2020, the number of acutely food insecure people could be 270 million. The impacts of the pandemic and climate change are seriously affecting food systems worldwide.
Fourth, climate change exacerbate humanitarian needs and extreme weather events. The desert locust outbreak from late 2019 was the worst in 25 years in the Horn of Africa. A series of flooding situations have taken place in 2020 where we have seen increased humanitarian needs and the displacement of vulnerable populations in contexts such as Sahel, South-East Asia, Sudan, Afghanistan, Ethiopia and South Sudan.
Fifth, as a result of the above, displacements are at record high levels. Conflict, violence and natural disasters drive people to seek refuge in either their country of origin or by crossing international borders. The majority of the 80 million people living in displacement have been forced to seek refuge due to natural disasters. The number of refugees, most of which seek refuge in neighbouring countries, has doubled from 10 million to 20 million in 10 years.
Sida’s humanitarian allocation to FAO in 2021
Sida´s humanitarian assistance is based on the four humanitarian principles, in particular impartiality, with its compelling urge to ensure that humanitarian action is carried out based on needs alone, giving priority to the most urgent cases of distress. Hence, Sida’s allocation methodology is grounded in several objective indicators such as; the scale of humanitarian needs (number of people in need), the severity of humanitarian needs (including food insecurity/IPC levels), the number of people targeted for the humanitarian response, the financial coverage of the respective humanitarian appeal, national capacities to respond and underlying risks, as well as distinct indicators related to forgotten crises. The allocation and subsequent disbursement of funds takes place in the beginning of the year to ensure predictability for Sida’s strategic humanitarian partners and to allow for optimal operational planning.
Based on Sida's humanitarian needs-based allocation process in late 2020 the following is proposed for FAO in 2021:
- Annual Projects/Programmes in line with Humanitarian Response Plans (usually 12 months) - 67 000 000 SEK - Rapid Response Mechanism (SFERA) - 25 000 000 SEK - Method Development and Capacity-Building - 2 000 000 SEK
This means that the total initial contribution to FAO in 2021 amounts to 94 000 000 SEK.
Annual Projects/Programmes (in line with the 2021 Humanitarian Response Plans):
- Afghanistan: 30 000 000 SEK
- Nigeria: 9 000 000 SEK
- Somalia: 12 000 000 SEK
- Somalia (FSNAU): 4 000 000 SEK
- South Sudan: 12 000 000 SEK
Rapid Response Mechanism or unallocated funds:
- SFERA: 25 000 000 SEK
Method- and capacity-building support
- Global Food Security Cluster: 2 000 000 SEK

FAO’s Global Goals are: 1. Eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition, progressively ensuring a world in which people at all times have sufficient safe and nutritious food that meets their dietary needs and food preferences for an active and healthy life; 2. Elimination of poverty and the driving forward of economic and social progress for all, with increased food production, enhanced rural development and sustainable livelihoods; 3. Sustainable management and utilization of natural resources, including land, water, air, climate and genetic resources for the benefit of present and future generations. Based on the global goals, FAO has formulated five strategic objectives: 1. Contribute to the eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition 2. Make agriculture, forestry and fisheries more productive and sustainable 3. Reduce rural poverty 4. Enable more inclusive and efficient agricultural and food systems 5. Increase the resilience of livelihoods to threats and crises The Strategic Framework also includes a sixth, broad objective on technical quality, knowledge and services (including cross-cutting themes) that is designed to cover FAO’s internal capability to deliver its strategic objectives. The objectives are in alignment with FAO’s commitment to working in partnerships. In humanitarian crises, FAO’s main components are: To help people to anticipate and prepare for crises; To respond fast to crises; To seek to reduce risks and address vulnerabilities. The humanitarian operations are usually related to the 5th strategic objective which has the four following organizational outcomes (OO): OO1 - countries and regions have legal, policy and institutional systems and regulatory frameworks for disaster and crisis risk management for agriculture, food and nutrition; OO2 - countries and regions deliver regular information and trigger timely actions against potential, known and emerging threats to agriculture, food, and nutrition; OO3 - countries apply prevention and impact mitigation measures that reduce risks for agriculture, food and nutrition; OO4 - countries and regions affected by disasters and crises with impact on agriculture, food and nutrition are prepared for, and manage effective responses. At the next level in the FAO Strategic Framework, there are a number of outputs pertinent to humanitarian action, such as: Output 4.1: Humanitarian action effectively protect lives and livelihoods of farmers, herders, Fishers, forest- and tree-dependent communities and marginal groups in times of crises. Output 3.1: Strategies and related interventions improve the resilience of livelihoods systems at risk through prevention and mitigation efforts that minimize the potential impacts of disasters and crises on agriculture food and nutrition at national, subnational and community levels. Output 2.2: Improved capacities of countries and communities to identify monitor and evaluate risks; conduct needs assessment and response analysis; and act on impending threats to agriculture, nutrition, food security and food safety (and related public health issues). Output 3.3: Conflict-sensitive programmes on agriculture, food and nutrition reduce the risks of localized conflicts relating to access to grazing, forest and farming lands, fishing grounds, water, trees and other natural resources. As Sida support FAO’s operations through a variety of different projects in different contexts, this appraisal does not include an overarching results framework. In the annual follow up reading up to Sida’s conclusion on performance all individual project reports will be analysed and assessed.

title.narrative: Standard Contribution Agreement between Sweden and The food and Agriculture Organization of the united Nations on support to humanitarian operations 2021-2025

description.narrative: Från 1:a januari 2019 till och med 31:a mars 2020 bidrog Sida med 249 miljoner kronor till 17 humanitära insatser implementerade av FAO över hela världen, varav tio i Afrika (Kamerun, Centralafrikanska republiken, Tchad , Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Somalia, Uganda och Zimbabwe); två i Asien (Afghanistan och Nordkorea); två i Mellanöstern (Irak och Syrien); en i Centralamerika (Guatemala/Nicaragua); samt stöd till det globala livsmedelsklustret. Nedan följer några exempel från de genomförda projekten: - Sida-finansiering i Afghanistan bidrog till att tillhandahålla akut livsmedelsbistånd för jordbrukare och boskapsskötare som drabbats av torka. Projektet bidrog till att stärka kapaciteten i jordbruket och förbättra livsmedelstryggheten. Projektet nådde 52 800 människor med exempelvis tillgång till utsäde och djurfoder samt teknisk utbildning kring boskapsskötsel och jordbruksproduktion. - I Centralafrikanska republiken finansierade Sida ett projekt som nådde 14 200 hushåll med utsäde i syfte att förbättra livsmedelstryggheten och bidra till en återställd jordbruksproduktion. Sida finansierade även utbildningar kring jordbruksproduktion. - I Nigeria har det Sida-finanseriade FAO-projektet bidragit till ökad livsmedelstrygghet och förbättrade nutritionsnivåer samt stärkt skydd för 27 330 hushåll utsatta för konflikt genom kontantbaserat stöd, vaccinationskampanjer för boskap, tillhandahållande av utsäde, upprättande av grönsaksodlingar samt insatser för lokalt sparande och lån (VSLA). - I Somalia finansierade Sida två projekt, varav ett bidrog till stärkt analytisk kapacitet för att förebygga naturkatastrofer och försämrad livsmedelstrygghet samt kapacitetsutveckling av nationella institutioners kapacitet inom detta område. Det andra projektet bidrog till förbättrad livsmedelstrygghet för 10 140 jordbrukande hushåll samt till att stärka jordbrukets motståndskraft mot framtida kriser och katastrofer.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

According to the Global Humanitarian Overview, in 2021, 235 million people will be in need of humanitarian assistance and protection – a substantial increase compared to 2020 which started out with nearly 168 million people in need. Thus resulting in yet another year with the highest number of people in need ever recorded by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). In parallel with staggering numbers of people in need, the funding gap increases and according to OCHA’s Financial Tracking Service (FTS), response plans and appeals were only 46% funded in 2020, compared to 61% in 2019. In 2021 the UN and partner organisations aim to help 160 million people most in need across 56 countries, with an estimated requirement of 35 billion USD.
Both the increase in people in need and funding gap can be partly derived from the COVID-19 pandemic. Putting additional pressure onto an already strained humanitarian system with limited resources. Although COVID-19 has definitely been centre stage during 2020, there are still other worrying trends affecting the global humanitarian outlook for 2021.
First, the COVID-19 pandemic has further exacerbated the vulnerability of the least protected populations. The pandemic has triggered the deepest global recession since the 1930s. Extreme poverty has risen for the first time in 22 years, and unemployment has increased dramatically. The impact of the socio-economic situation will continue to have serious implications on humanitarian needs in 2021.
Second, political conflicts are more intense and are taking a heavy toll on civilians, disproportionally affecting children. Women and girls are at increased risk of conflict-related sexual violence. As such, protecting those affected by armed conflict is more crucial than ever. The lack of respect for International Humanitarian Law (IHL) continues to be one of the most pressing challenges. Armed conflicts continue to cause enormous suffering, including violations of IHL, such as killings, torture, abductions and displacements. Applying a protection lens/Centrality of Protection approach is essential – in light of the protection crises such as the Syria crisis - now active for more than a decade; Yemen - being the largest humanitarian crisis worldwide; the DR Congo; the Venezuela crisis; the Nagorno-Karabach situation and the Rohingya crisis – just to mention a few.
Third, hunger is on the rise, with conflict the main driver of acute hunger for 77 million people in 22 countries. By the end of 2020, the number of acutely food insecure people could be 270 million. The impacts of the pandemic and climate change are seriously affecting food systems worldwide.
Fourth, climate change exacerbate humanitarian needs and extreme weather events. The desert locust outbreak from late 2019 was the worst in 25 years in the Horn of Africa. A series of flooding situations have taken place in 2020 where we have seen increased humanitarian needs and the displacement of vulnerable populations in contexts such as Sahel, South-East Asia, Sudan, Afghanistan, Ethiopia and South Sudan.
Fifth, as a result of the above, displacements are at record high levels. Conflict, violence and natural disasters drive people to seek refuge in either their country of origin or by crossing international borders. The majority of the 80 million people living in displacement have been forced to seek refuge due to natural disasters. The number of refugees, most of which seek refuge in neighbouring countries, has doubled from 10 million to 20 million in 10 years.

Sida´s humanitarian assistance is based on the four humanitarian principles, in particular impartiality, with its compelling urge to ensure that humanitarian action is carried out based on needs alone, giving priority to the most urgent cases of distress. Hence, Sida’s allocation methodology is grounded in several objective indicators such as; the scale of humanitarian needs (number of people in need), the severity of humanitarian needs (including food insecurity/IPC levels), the number of people targeted for the humanitarian response, the financial coverage of the respective humanitarian appeal, national capacities to respond and underlying risks, as well as distinct indicators related to forgotten crises. The allocation and subsequent disbursement of funds takes place in the beginning of the year to ensure predictability for Sida’s strategic humanitarian partners and to allow for optimal operational planning.
Based on Sida's humanitarian needs-based allocation process in late 2020 the following is proposed for FAO in 2021:
- Annual Projects/Programmes in line with Humanitarian Response Plans (usually 12 months) - 67 000 000 SEK - Rapid Response Mechanism (SFERA) - 25 000 000 SEK - Method Development and Capacity-Building - 2 000 000 SEK
This means that the total initial contribution to FAO in 2021 amounts to 94 000 000 SEK.
Annual Projects/Programmes (in line with the 2021 Humanitarian Response Plans):
- Afghanistan: 30 000 000 SEK
- Nigeria: 9 000 000 SEK
- Somalia: 12 000 000 SEK
- Somalia (FSNAU): 4 000 000 SEK
- South Sudan: 12 000 000 SEK
Rapid Response Mechanism or unallocated funds:
- SFERA: 25 000 000 SEK
Method- and capacity-building support
- Global Food Security Cluster: 2 000 000 SEK

FAO’s Global Goals are: 1. Eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition, progressively ensuring a world in which people at all times have sufficient safe and nutritious food that meets their dietary needs and food preferences for an active and healthy life; 2. Elimination of poverty and the driving forward of economic and social progress for all, with increased food production, enhanced rural development and sustainable livelihoods; 3. Sustainable management and utilization of natural resources, including land, water, air, climate and genetic resources for the benefit of present and future generations. Based on the global goals, FAO has formulated five strategic objectives: 1. Contribute to the eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition 2. Make agriculture, forestry and fisheries more productive and sustainable 3. Reduce rural poverty 4. Enable more inclusive and efficient agricultural and food systems 5. Increase the resilience of livelihoods to threats and crises The Strategic Framework also includes a sixth, broad objective on technical quality, knowledge and services (including cross-cutting themes) that is designed to cover FAO’s internal capability to deliver its strategic objectives. The objectives are in alignment with FAO’s commitment to working in partnerships.
